advaita_philosophy.definition: Advaita Vedanta is a school of Hindu philosophy that teaches non-dualism, asserting that the individual self (Atman) and the ultimate reality (Brahman) are one and the same.
core_principles: Brahman is the only reality; the world is an illusion (Maya).
Atman (individual soul) is identical to Brahman.
Ignorance (Avidya) causes the illusion of separateness.

key_concepts.brahman: The ultimate, infinite, and changeless reality.
key_concepts.atman: The true self, beyond body and mind.
key_concepts.maya: Illusion that creates the perception of multiplicity.
key_concepts.avidya: Ignorance that binds beings to Samsara.

goals: Realize the unity of Atman and Brahman.

relation_to_other_concepts.dharma: Ethical living supports clarity for realization.
relation_to_other_concepts.karma: Actions cannot grant liberation; only knowledge can.

key_scriptural_references.quote_summary: The wise see the same Self in all beings.
